channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Indianapolis Police Fatally Shoot Man Who May Have Streamed Encounter on Facebook Live
item.description: The police said the man was killed after shooting at an officer who chased him for driving recklessly. The man apparently recorded a video several minutes long during the pursuit.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
item.media:description: Indianapolis residents gathered at the scene of a shooting on Wednesday.

item.title: Coronavirus Reopenings: Many Churches Consider Plans to Pray in Person
item.description: Many churches across the country, closed for physical worship for nearly two months, are contemplating what’s next.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Dias
item.media:description: The sun rising behind a church near Commerce, Texas, on May 1. Amid the pandemic, churches in America are wondering how to operate in the longer term.

item.title: ‘Covid-19 Parties’ Probably Didn’t Involve Intentional Spread
item.description: County health officials in Washington State walked back earlier claims that young people were gathering in a deliberate attempt to be exposed to the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker
item.media:description: Walla Walla, Wash. With some people expressing eagerness to get the coronavirus, officials in Walla Walla, Wash., are investigating two parties at which infected people were present.

item.title: How a Daily Walk Helps Us Cope With the Coronavi
item.description: We asked readers to tell us about the walks they are taking, what they see on their travels and how they feel as they cover old ground or forge new paths.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Northeast Forecast Has Cold and Snow On the Way
item.description: An Arctic blast will sweep parts of the Northeast, bringing record-cold temperatures and even some snow to states that are coming out of a mild winter.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer and Henry Fountain
item.media:description: A dusting of snow in Stowe, Vt., on Tuesday. Unseasonably cold weather is expected to move into the Northeast on Friday night.

item.title: Woman Opens Fire in McDonald’s Partly Closed Over Virus Concerns, Police Say
item.description: At least three employees were injured after one told a woman that the dining area was closed, the police said. The McDonald’s chief executive called it a “heinous crime” against workers trying to protect public health.
item.dc:creator: Mihir Zaveri
item.media:description: The police responding to a shooting at a McDonald’s in southwest Oklahoma City on Wednesday.

item.title: U.S. Military Killed 132 Civilians in Wars Last Year, Pentagon Says
item.description: The tally has changed little since the previous year’s report, which put the total at 120 civilians killed. Civilian deaths in Afghanistan again eclipsed those in Syria and Iraq.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: An American military vehicle at Bagram Air Field in Afghanistan last year.

item.title: Supreme Court Unanimously Overturns ‘Bridgegate’ Convictions
item.description: The court said there was evidence of wrongdoing but not of a federal crime.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.category: Port Authority of New York and New Jersey
item.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bridget Anne Kelly and Bill Baroni leaving a federal courthouse in Newark, N.J., in 2016.

item.title: Government Orders Alone Didn’t Close the Economy. They Probably Can’t Reopen It.
item.description: Data shows there was a drop in spending and working even before any official mandates to stay at home.
item.dc:creator: Emily Badger and Alicia Parlapiano
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)

item.title: Generic Drug Maker to Admit to Fixing Prices for Cholesterol Medication
item.description: Apotex will admit conspiring to inflate drug prices, pay $24 million and cooperate with the Justice Department’s investigation into the pharmaceutical industry.
item.dc:creator: Katie Benner
item.media:description: Apotex’s manufacturing plant in Toronto.

item.title: Wildfires in Florida Panhandle Force Hundreds to Evacuate
item.description: More than 1,000 residents were told to move away from fires that a state official called “extremely dangerous.”
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser
item.media:credit: Florida Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The fire broke out on Monday afternoon and has grown, fanned by high winds and low humidity, officials said.

item.title: Coronavirus, President Trump, India: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Janie Osborne for The New York Times
item.media:description: A coal-fired generating station in Sidney, Mont.

item.title: As Restaurants Remain Shuttered, American Cities Fear the Future
item.description: Restaurants have become the economic lifeblood for many cities. The coronavirus threatens to take away more than just delicious food.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Steinhauer and Pete Wells
item.media:credit: Whitney Curtis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Olio, an Italian restaurant in St. Louis, was converted from an old gas station.

item.title: Knock, Knock, Who’s There? No Political Canvassers, for the First Time Maybe Ever
item.description: Candidates and political parties are struggling to plan for a fall campaign without some of the most basic building blocks of politics.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher
item.media:credit: Jordan Gale for The New York Times
item.media:description: A sign for former Vice President Jospeh R. Biden Jr. was left on a door by a canvasser in Dubuque, Iowa, in January. Showing up on doorsteps has long been one of the most reliable ways to get people to vote.

item.title: His Day Job: Cory Booker’s Top Aide. His Night One: E.M.S. Volunteer.
item.description: When coronavirus cases rose in New Jersey, Matt Klapper, a former firefighter and ambulance crew chief, answered a call for retired medical workers to help out.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer
item.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times
item.media:description: Matt Klapper, the chief of staff for Senator Cory Booker, pulled an ambulance into the bay at the squad dispatch in Springfield, N.J., last week.

item.title: Travel From New York City Seeded Wave of U.S. Outbreaks
item.description: The coronavirus outbreak in New York City became the primary source of infections around the United States, researchers have found.
item.dc:creator: Benedict Carey and James Glanz

item.title: UnitedHealth Customers Will See a Discount on Next Month’s Bill
item.description: The insurer has seen its earnings rise during the pandemic, so it’s awarding premium credits to people enrolled in its plans.
item.dc:creator: Reed Abelson
item.media:description: UnitedHealth Group has decided to return a part of its profits during the pandemic to enrollees.

item.title: Coronavirus World News: Live Updates
item.description: The United Nations tripled the size of its humanitarian aid appeal, citing a global food shortage created by the virus. In India, a lethal gas leak may have resulted from a rush to reopen a chemical plant.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: A beach in Barcelona, Spain, was empty last month.

item.title: 3.2 Million Filed for Unemployment Benefits Last Week: Live Updates
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Neiman Marcus was forced to close its 43 stores across the country because of the pandemic.

item.title: Brett Favre to Repay $1.1 Million for Speeches He Didn’t Make, Auditor Says
item.description: The Hall of Fame quarterback was the unknowing recipient of money intended to help needy families in his home state, Mississippi, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:description: N.F.L. Hall of Fame player Brett Favre accepted more than $1 million in speaking fees from the Mississippi Community Education Center over the course of a year.

item.title: Trump Vetoes Measure Demanding Congressional Approval for Iran Conflict
item.description: The president said the resolution was an “insulting” move to limit his powers as commander in chief.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: President Trump said he considered the resolution a personal attack and an infringement on his powers as commander of the military.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: People who have recovered from Covid-19 describe what it really feels like to endure the disease.
item.dc:creator: Patrick J. Lyons

item.title: Trump’s New Message: Time to Move On to the Economic Recovery
item.description: The president’s cure-can’t-be-worse-than-the-disease logic is clear: As bad as the virus may be, the cost of the virtual national lockdown has grown too high.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: President Trump has focused on the economic fallout of the coronavirus.

item.title: ‘I’m Sure for American Women, This Is Frustrating’
item.description: We spoke to the chief executive of Time’s Up about Joe Biden, Tara Reade and what this moment says about how the country thinks about sexual misconduct.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tina Tchen is the chief executive officer of Time’s Up.

item.title: Gen. Frederick Kroesen, 97, Dies; Survived a Terrorist Attack
item.description: The commander of troops in Europe, he had faced enemy fire in three wars before emerging with only cuts from a rocket attack by radical West German leftists in 1981.
item.dc:creator: Richard Goldstein
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Sinclair Wanted to Rival Fox News. Now It Faces a $48 Million Fine.
item.description: The F.C.C. levied the largest civil penalty in its history against a conservative owner of local TV stations, scuttling its ambitious merger plans.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor and Edmund Lee
item.media:description: Sinclair Broadcast Group had hoped to take control of 215 stations across the country in a deal with Tribune Media in 2017.

item.title: Online Retailers Spend Millions on Ads Backing Postal Service Bailout
item.description: The coalition, which includes Amazon, plans to pour $2 million into ads opposing President Trump’s call for higher package delivery rates and pressing for Congress to help the service.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:description: Postal Service employees sorting packages in Los Angeles last month. The pandemic has cut into the service’s revenue and mail volume.

item.title: As Hunger Swells, Food Stamps Become a Partisan Flash Point
item.description: Democrats are seeking to raise benefits as research shows a rise in food insecurity without modern precedent amid the pandemic. But Republicans have balked at a long-term expansion of the program.
item.dc:creator: Jason DeParle
item.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volunteers preparing food at a distribution center in Egg Harbor Township, N.J., last month.

item.title: 3 People Killed in Shooting at California High School Parking Lot
item.description: The three teenagers were killed in a shooting at Golden West High School in Visalia, Calif. The police said they were not students there.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:credit: Sheyanne N Romero/The Times-Delta, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A damaged fence outside Golden West High School in Visalia, Calif. Three teenagers, none of whom were students at the school, were killed in a shooting in the parking lot there on Tuesday night.

item.title: Democrats Press Judicial Nominee, a McConnell Protégé, on Health Care Views
item.description: Judge Justin Walker seems headed for confirmation to an important appeals court despite concerns by critics that he would help unravel the Affordable Care Act.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.media:description: Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky and the majority leader, has known Judge Walker since the judge was in high school.

item.title: Coronavirus Makes Cooling Centers Risky, Just as Scorching Weather Hits
item.description: Officials are scrambling to find ways to protect residents against dueling threats of extreme heat and the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle
item.media:description: American cities traditionally rely on cooling centers to protect the most vulnerable. Above, a center for older people near Times Square in 2006.

item.title: Israeli High Court Lets Netanyahu Form Government, Despite Indictments
item.description: The court ruling clears the last major obstacle to Mr. Netanyahu’s claiming a record fifth term as Israel’s leader.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger and Adam Rasgon
item.media:credit: Dan Balilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel during an event in Kiryat Arba, an Israeli settlement in the West Bank, in February.

item.title: To Fight Virus in Prisons, C.D.C. Suggests More Screenings
item.description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention confirmed that detention facilities are hot spots for infection and recommended regular symptom screenings.
item.dc:creator: David Waldstein
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: An inmate cleaning a jail cell at Las Colinas Women’s Detention Facility in Santee, Calif., last month.

item.title: Auto Plant Shutdown Spares an Essential: Corvette Parts
item.description: Big U.S. automakers have kept the lights on at a few factories, including a General Motors plant in Indiana making the Corvette chassis.
item.dc:creator: Noam Scheiber
item.media:credit: Kaiti Sullivan for The New York Times
item.media:description: The General Motors plant in Bedford, Ind., makes chassis for Chevrolet Corvettes.

item.title: Are You Paying Extra for Eggs? Lawsuits Accuse Producers of Price Gouging
item.description: Separate lawsuits in California and Texas contend that egg producers or supermarkets charged excessive, illegal prices for eggs amid the coronavirus pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: Eggs have been in high demand during the coronavirus pandemic. The average wholesale price for Grade A large eggs surged from $1.01 to $3.07 per dozen in March, according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture.

item.title: The Compost by My Couch: How (and Why) I Started an Odorless Bin at Home
item.description: New York City has suspended its composting program because of the coronavirus. Here’s an alternative that’s easy, clean and good for the climate.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:description: An organic waste bin in New York. The city has stopped collecting compost because of budget cuts related to the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Did a Mutation Turbocharge the Coronavirus? Not Likely, Scientists Say
item.description: A preliminary report posted online claimed that a mutation had made the virus more transmissible. Geneticists say the evidence isn’t there.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer
item.media:credit: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, via Reuters
item.media:description: A colored scanning electron micrograph of a dying cell infected with the coronavirus, with viral particles in red.

item.title: A Place in the U.S. With No Covid-19? Look to American Samoa.
item.description: The territory, which has sealed itself off from the outside world, has no confirmed cases.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero
item.media:credit: Gabby Fa'ai'uaso for The New York Times
item.media:description: Some credit American Samoa’s good fortune to its enduring memories of the 1918 influenza epidemic, which wiped out much of neighboring Samoa’s population.

item.title: Supreme Court Divided Over Obamacare’s Contraceptive Mandate
item.description: The justices considered whether the Trump administration may allow employers to refuse to provide free insurance coverage for birth control on religious or moral grounds.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.media:description: About 70,000 to 126,000 women could lose contraceptive coverage from their employers if the Trump administration prevails.
